messages.text:
Hi a question regarding multiple dispatch. In the performance tips they warn against abusing multiple dispatch. I was wondering whether the following is best practice:

I have a 2x2 block matrix type:
```struct BlockMatrix{T, T11 <: AbstractMatrix{T}, T12 <: AbstractMatrix{T}, T21 <: AbstractMatrix{T}, T22 <: AbstractMatrix{T}} <: AbstractMatrix{T}
  A11::T11
  A12::T12
  A21::T21
  A22::T22

  # inner constructor etc. checks for consistency among dimensions...
end```
so routines that use `BlockMatrix` potentially dispatch on many different combinations depending on the arrays they get no? Would this be the best way to do it?

messages.text:
I have a struct with custom equality semantics. I have added methods for `==` and `isequal` which work most of the time, but they break when comparing sets of these objects.
```julia> rwm1 == deepcopy(rwm1)
true

julia> [rwm1] == [deepcopy(rwm1)]
true

julia> Set([rwm1]) == Set([deepcopy(rwm1)])
false```
What method should I add so that set comparisons also work for these structs? I am using Julia 1.6.

What method should I add so that set comparisons also work for these structs? I am using Julia 1.6.

Hey all, I have a brain teaser for you that has stumped me:

Say if I have a matrix like this:

``` [39.0   2.0  26.0  12.0  33.0  28.0  20.0
 21.0  50.0   9.0  38.0   3.0  30.0   0.0
 42.0  40.0   8.0  34.0   4.0  10.0  24.0
 46.0  14.0  15.0  22.0   6.0  45.0  18.0]```
Which is represented by the LinearIndices Matrix:

``` 1  5   9  13  17  21  25
 2  6  10  14  18  22  26
 3  7  11  15  19  23  27
 4  8  12  16  20  24  28```
What I have been trying to figure out is how to find location groups with similar values. In my case, I am trying to make groups within 5 units of each other which would give me value groupings like this: `[42, 46, 40], [9, 8], [14, 15]` etc. and associated position groups: `[3, 4, 7], [10, 11], [8, 12]`. I have been able to find where all the "similar values" (as shown by the matrix below where #'s represent similar values and *'s represent unsimiliar values) are but cannot determine how to break down these similar values to groups as I showed with the value grouping.

``` "*"  "*"  "*"  "*"  "#"  "#"  "*"
 "*"  "*"  "#"  "#"  "#"  "#"  "*"
 "#"  "#"  "#"  "#"  "#"  "*"  "*"
 "#"  "*"  "*"  "*"  "#"  "*"  "*"```
Does anyone have any idea on how I could best get these groupings? Frankly, this feels a lot like a recursive sort of problem but I may be overthinking it. Thank you!

messages.text:
This multithreading behavior with a weird "fix" happens on 1.4.2 for me, but not 1.5 or 1.6.  I don't understand what I'm doing wrong, so I'm wary of just upgrading and forgetting about it:
```module M

function f()
    x = zeros(Int, 10000)

    Threads.@threads for i in 1:length(x)
        n = i
        x[n] = n
    end

    n = sum(x) # weird behavior "fixed" if we change 'n' to 
    return n   # some other name here and here
end

println(f()) # should print 50005000, but does not

end```
But instead of printing 50005000 at the end, we get a random number each time we run.  This is seemingly fixed by changing
```n = sum(x)
return n```
to
```a = sum(x)
return a```
Am I misunderstanding scoping for `n` inside `@threads`? Thank you!

messages.text:
What DateFormat string can be used to parse strings in the format returned by `ctime()`?  The first 9 days of a month seem problematic because they have a double space between the month and day field (more technically a single space between the month field and the space-left-padded two character day field):
```Thu Apr  1 23:40:40 2021```
`dateformat"e u  d HH:MM:SS yyyy"` works for the first 9 days, but from the 10th onwards the double space in the format string doesn't work.  Likewise, using a single space in the DateFormat string works for the 10th onward, but doesn't work for the first 9 days.  What to do?   :man-shrugging:

Is this a known issue?
```julia> 0 .* (1:3) .+ (1:4)'
ERROR: ArgumentError: step cannot be zero```
It seems to be evaluating `0 .* (1:3)` too early, when it ought to be fused into the larger broadcast.

messages.text:
Hey any of you `Weave.jl`  experts out there. I was wondering if there is a way to specify the folder for the images produced when weaving a file? So say I have plots that are generated from a `*.jmd` file. Those plot png files get saved in a `figures` folder. Is there a way to specify the exact location of the figures, such as in the `figures/lecture1/` folder instead? I checked the Figure chunk options and the header options and did not see this. This way, I can directly move the output html or md file to a different directory and move the figures to a different directory without breaking the links in the output md file.

Note that the `output_path` option will set the location for the output pdf or html file, but I am just trying to change where the figures themselves are saved.

Hello! its me again, I'm now running into a string comparison issue, essentially my package is reading text from a document and I have typed the expected string as part of the text, problem is that the text read has different codepoints which makes the comparison yield inequality, here's an excerpt of the test evaluations:

```  Expression: result[i] == expected[i]
   Evaluated: ' ' == ' '
  Expression: codepoint(result[i]) == codepoint(expected[i])
   Evaluated: 0x000000a0 == 0x00000020```
As you can see the strings/chars "are the same" yet they have different code points, is there a function that "normalizes" this sort of thing?

messages.text:
Problem with Julia 1.6.0 and previous using processes. I am using Distributed package to concurrently compute something, and when I start julia -p 20 it works ok. But I want to make a binary bundle, and than somehow default shown by julia --help "auto" launches as many workers as the number of local CPU threads (logical cores)" for -p parameter, allocates only 1 thread, so compiled binary also uses 1 thread. I think this is Julia issue not detecting correctly number of physical cores of my CPU.
I am running julia binary from website on GNU/Linux Debian x86.

messages.text: I'm trying to have a struct that stores different representations of a matrix. My primary matrix representation is a `SimpleWeightedGraph{Int32, Float32}` from which I want to construct different representations (like the degree matrix, laplacian, etc). I saw that `LightGraphs.jl` provides `CombinatorialAdjacency`, `NormalizedAdjacency` and `NormalizedLaplacian` types, which I'd like to have in my struct. However, I keep running into all kinds of type mismatch errors when I try to cast between my `SimpleWeightedGraph` and the other representations in LightGraphs.jl. I might be going about this wrong, so I'd help any and all help in trying to figure this out. P.S. Is there some kind of type incompatibility between `Float32` and `NormalizedLaplacian`/`NormalizedAdjacency` ? I remember a SparseMatrix of type `Float64` working, but `Float32` gave me some type errors, back from when I was hacking about. messages.text:
A question on functional programming and efficiency... I am suspecting that I am slowing down my code significanly with the following few lines:
```  Lmul = (y, _, x) ->  y = Abi*blockldiv!(D, x) # this is just some matrix arithmetic
  Lmulc = (y, _, x) ->  y = blockrdiv!((x'*Abi), D)'
  Lop = LinearOperator{T}(size(Abi)..., Lmul, Lmulc, nothing)
  F = pqrfact(Lop, sketch=:randn, atol, rtol=rtol)```
A few remarks: I am using the `LowRankApprox`  package found here: <https://github.com/JuliaMatrices/LowRankApprox.jl>. The idea is to define `Lmul`  and `Lmulc`  as functions and compute a low-rank approximation on the fly without ever forming the matrix. I suspect however, that my code is highly inefficient for the compiler as `julia --track-allocation=user`  reports high memory usage on the function definition and LinearOperator. Any pointers as to what I am doing wrong here??

attachments.fallback:
[April 3rd, 2021 3:20 PM] bonevbs: follow-up question on a question i posted earlier:

I believe that I have a type stability issue with the following function:
```function _assemble_blocks(A::AbstractMatrix{T}, S1::AbstractMatrix{T}, S2::AbstractMatrix{T}, int1::Vector{Int}, int2::Vector{Int}, bnd1::Vector{Int}, bnd2::Vector{Int}; args...) where T
  ni1 = length(int1); nb1 = length(bnd1)
  ni2 = length(int2); nb2 = length(bnd2)
  Aii = BlockMatrix(S1[1:ni1, 1:ni1], A[int1, int2], A[int2, int1], S2[1:ni2, 1:ni2])
  Aib = BlockMatrix(S1[1:ni1, ni1+1:ni1+nb1], A[int1, bnd2], A[int2, bnd1], S2[1:ni2, ni2+1:ni2+nb2])
  Abi = BlockMatrix(S1[ni1+1:ni1+nb1, 1:ni1], A[bnd1, int2], A[bnd2, int1], S2[ni2+1:ni2+nb2, 1:ni2])
  Abb = BlockMatrix(S1[ni1+1:ni1+nb1, ni1+1:ni1+nb1], A[bnd1, bnd2], A[bnd2, bnd1], S2[ni2+1:ni2+nb2, ni2+1:ni2+nb2])
  return Aii, Aib, Abi, Abb
end```
`@code_warntype`  complains that the return type is `Ntuple{4,Any}`  and I believe that this is where all my trouble originates. The members of the tuple are all `BlockMatrix{T,T11,T12,T21,T22}`  types with same `T`  but different `T11`  etc. however they're all `AbstractArray` . Am I understanding it right that at the end when this ufnction gets called
```Aii, Aib, Abi, Abb = _assemble_blocks(...)```
type-inference stops working as `Aii`  is of type `Any` ? If so, what would be a better way of writing `_assemble_blocks` ? Should I define the return-type?
attachments.text:
follow-up question on a question i posted earlier:

I believe that I have a type stability issue with the following function:
```function _assemble_blocks(A::AbstractMatrix{T}, S1::AbstractMatrix{T}, S2::AbstractMatrix{T}, int1::Vector{Int}, int2::Vector{Int}, bnd1::Vector{Int}, bnd2::Vector{Int}; args...) where T
  ni1 = length(int1); nb1 = length(bnd1)
  ni2 = length(int2); nb2 = length(bnd2)
  Aii = BlockMatrix(S1[1:ni1, 1:ni1], A[int1, int2], A[int2, int1], S2[1:ni2, 1:ni2])
  Aib = BlockMatrix(S1[1:ni1, ni1+1:ni1+nb1], A[int1, bnd2], A[int2, bnd1], S2[1:ni2, ni2+1:ni2+nb2])
  Abi = BlockMatrix(S1[ni1+1:ni1+nb1, 1:ni1], A[bnd1, int2], A[bnd2, int1], S2[ni2+1:ni2+nb2, 1:ni2])
  Abb = BlockMatrix(S1[ni1+1:ni1+nb1, ni1+1:ni1+nb1], A[bnd1, bnd2], A[bnd2, bnd1], S2[ni2+1:ni2+nb2, ni2+1:ni2+nb2])
  return Aii, Aib, Abi, Abb
end```
`@code_warntype`  complains that the return type is `Ntuple{4,Any}`  and I believe that this is where all my trouble originates. The members of the tuple are all `BlockMatrix{T,T11,T12,T21,T22}`  types with same `T`  but different `T11`  etc. however they're all `AbstractArray` . Am I understanding it right that at the end when this ufnction gets called
```Aii, Aib, Abi, Abb = _assemble_blocks(...)```
type-inference stops working as `Aii`  is of type `Any` ? If so, what would be a better way of writing `_assemble_blocks` ? Should I define the return-type?

messages.text:
hi, a question on type-inference. I have a recusive type that distinguishes between leave-nodes and branch nodes of a tree-structure.
```struct LeafNode{T}
  data{T} # this holds something
end

struct BranchNode{T} where T
  left::Union{TreeNode{T}, BranchNode{T}}
  right::Union{TreeNode{T}, BranchNode{T}}
end

const TreeNode{T} = Union{TreeNode{T}, BranchNode{T}}```
as my Julia-skills progressed with the package while writing it, I might not have realized that this might have been a mistake. In particular, I thought that this is nice as most algorithms should behave differently if they encounter a leaf node.

One of the things that I noticed is that this definition seems to be problematic for type-inference as `getproperty`  does not always give you the same return type on the treenode. Are there easy ways to redeem this apart from a complete rewrite?

as my Julia-skills progressed with the package while writing it, I might not have realized that this might have been a mistake. In particular, I thought that this is nice as most algorithms should behave differently if they encounter a leaf node.

does not always give you the same return type on the treenode. Are there easy ways to redeem this apart from a complete rewrite?

messages.text:
Could someone help me find a less-ugly way to do something? I have a function `dom_cws!()` (takes no arguments) which, when called on a remote process (i.e. `@spawnat 2 dom_cws!()`), performs some computation local to that process.  Anyway, I want to run `dom_cws!()`  on each worker process asynchronously and then wait for each to complete before moving on.

My first attempt at this is written below:

`fs = Array{Future}(undef, nworkers())`
`for (i, w) in enumerate(workers())`   
    `fs[i] = @spawnat w dom_cws!()`    
`end`                                  
`[wait(f) for f in fs]`   

but this seemed too wordy. My next attempt was:

`pmap((_) -> dom_cws!(), 1:nworkers())`

but I’m implicitly using the fact that pmap works on each available worker process by default. While succinct, this seems gross. Is there a better way to do this? Maybe there is some macro I’m not aware of?

Thanks for the help! I’m new to Distributed so this may be a little basic.

messages.text:
Spawning this off to the rest of the community. Zygote will be able to nest derivatives in most cases if its `getindex` adjoint wasn't mutating. Here's the code:

```∇getindex(x::AbstractArray, inds) = dy -> begin
  if inds isa  NTuple{<:Any, Integer}
    allinds = eachindex(x)
    ininds(i) = i ∈ inds
    dx = ifelse.(_zero(x, typeof(dy))
    dx[inds...] = dy
  else
    dx = _zero(x, eltype(dy))
    dxv = view(dx, inds...)
    dxv .= accum.(dxv, _droplike(dy, dxv))
  end
  return (dx, map(_->nothing, inds)...)
end```
So first of all, there's two different dispatches (or should be, grumble grumble). On those two dispatches, does anyone see a quick way to make them non-mutating?

<https://github.com/FluxML/Zygote.jl/issues/820>

elements.text: Spawning this off to the rest of the community. Zygote will be able to nest derivatives in most cases if its
adjoint wasn't mutating. Here's the code:

∇getindex(x::AbstractArray, inds) = dy -> begin
  if inds isa  NTuple{<:Any, Integer}
    allinds = eachindex(x)
    ininds(i) = i ∈ inds
    dx = ifelse.(_zero(x, typeof(dy))
    dx[inds...] = dy
  else
    dx = _zero(x, eltype(dy))
    dxv = view(dx, inds...)
    dxv .= accum.(dxv, _droplike(dy, dxv))
  end
  return (dx, map(_->nothing, inds)...)
end
So first of all, there's two different dispatches (or should be, grumble grumble). On those two dispatches, does anyone see a quick way to make them non-mutating?

Hi guys.. I have a question related to some of the questions I have asked here before. I have a code which produces a slight instability in one the outputs `Aii`  which is a `BlockMatrix{T, T11, T12, T21, T22}`  object:
```Aii, .. = assemble_blocks(...)```
I then generate functions at runtime
```Lmul = (y, _, x) -> y .= Aii\(Aib*x)```
which from my understanding is type-instable and also leads to compiling the function everytime anew as it is generated. However, I need to pass this function to another library `LowRankApprox.jl` , and I do not really have a choice on the function signature. In other words, i need to generate new functions for every new `Aii`  etc. that I compute.

I tried to circumvent these problems as previously suggested here by introducing more function barriers as so:
```function _gauss_transforms(Aii, Aib)
  return (y, _, x) -> y 
end```
or
```Lmul = (y, _, x) -> _gauss_transform(Aii, Aib, y, x)```
but to no avail.

Any suggestions on how to avoid this performance issue? I am at the end of my wisdom...
Another issue I have is that I do not know how to debug the generated functions. `@code_warntype Lmul(x)`  returns nothing at all.

I am grateful for any help and suggestions :slightly_smiling_face:

messages.text: Are Julia `Channel`s thread-safe? Could I have multiple `Task` s on multiple threads each push data to the same `Channel` without locking?

elements.text: s thread-safe? Could I have multiple
s on multiple threads each push data to the same

messages.text: Yes. This is what Channels are meant to be for.

elements.text: Yes. This is what Channels are meant to be for.

messages.text: To the same channel though?
I mean, they're definitely threadsafe insofar only one thread can insert at a given time

elements.text: I mean, they're definitely threadsafe insofar only one thread can insert at a given time

messages.text: Thats the price for thread safety. You have to block the given structure until the operation is done. Then you can unblock this. But we speak about nano seconds and an inter task communication channel. For instance you can try to sum from 1 to 1000000 with more then one task to the same variable. If you didn’t block this in the right way you get unpredictable results.

elements.text: Thats the price for thread safety. You have to block the given structure until the operation is done. Then you can unblock this. But we speak about nano seconds and an inter task communication channel. For instance you can try to sum from 1 to 1000000 with more then one task to the same variable. If you didn’t block this in the right way you get unpredictable results.

messages.text: I frquently bump into this issue of not being allowed to use sparse right-hand sides when doing `A\B` , therefore having to do `A\convert(Matrix, B)` . It's a bit frustrating as the result can often be sparse regardless. In my opinion it would be better to get a warning in this case, as I think in many cases it could be useful to be able to stick to sparse arithmetic

messages.text:
Is there an `IOBuffer`-like thing that can make `readline` wait?
```julia> iob = IOBuffer()
IOBuffer(data=UInt8[...], readable=true, writable=true, seekable=true, append=false, size=0, maxsize=Inf, ptr=1, mark=-1)

julia> readline(iob)
"" # returns immediately

julia> readline(stdin)
 # waits for data```

elements.text:
julia> iob = IOBuffer()
IOBuffer(data=UInt8[...], readable=true, writable=true, seekable=true, append=false, size=0, maxsize=Inf, ptr=1, mark=-1)

julia> readline(iob)
"" # returns immediately

julia> readline(stdin)
 # waits for data

messages.text: Getting a `HTTP.ExceptionRequest.StatusError` when deploying docs, and I cannot figure whether the issue is with Plots, Literate, Documenter, another package, or my code. Please help! Details in thread!

elements.text: when deploying docs, and I cannot figure whether the issue is with Plots, Literate, Documenter, another package, or my code. Please help! Details in thread!

messages.text: So the issue is in <https://github.com/JuliaOcean/AIBECS.jl/pull/65/checks?check_run_id=2274261157#step:5:80|this PR preview docs> that was triggered by Compat Helper. Attached is the relevant portion of the stack trace. It looks like an HTTP.jl issue, but I am at a loss as to why that would be. The rest of the stacktrace just metions Literate.jl, which I'm not sure how to interpret either. FWIW, the cell that throws is a simple heatmap-type of recipes that worked perfectly fine before, and that cell comes after a bunch of fairly similar calls. Any help / pointers would be much appreciated! :pray:

elements.text: that was triggered by Compat Helper. Attached is the relevant portion of the stack trace. It looks like an HTTP.jl issue, but I am at a loss as to why that would be. The rest of the stacktrace just metions Literate.jl, which I'm not sure how to interpret either. FWIW, the cell that throws is a simple heatmap-type of recipes that worked perfectly fine before, and that cell comes after a bunch of fairly similar calls. Any help / pointers would be much appreciated!

messages.text:
Problem when attempt to have an Float64-array with specified amount of possible states.
```Array = rand(Float64, Parameters["Population_size"], Parameters["Genes"])
AF_Array = AFArray(Array)```
This works quite well, but problem is, that there must be x-states for values. When I code:
```Array = rand(0:Max_state, Parameters["Population_size"], Parameters["Genes"])
AF_Array = AFArray(Array)```
This gives an Int64-array, but when I try to decode it to an float-array 0..1 at another function:
```Decoded = Feed / Max_state```
Becomes problem, due "Decoded" wants to be an Int64-array and is filled with zeros, when it should be Float64-array.

How to fix it..? :thinking_face:

This gives an Int64-array, but when I try to decode it to an float-array 0..1 at another function:

How to fix it..?

messages.text: Hi, a question on `SparseMatrixCSC` . I have a code (a solver for linear systems) which should have quasilinear complexity in solving linear systems. Unfortunately I have one bottleneck which is extracting submatrices `A[i,j]` from the big sparse matrix. This should be an O(n log n) operation but it seems that the current implementation is infuriatingly slow and O(n^2). I have found some closed threads on discourse but it is unclear what the current status is on that. Any hints?

elements.text: . I have a code (a solver for linear systems) which should have quasilinear complexity in solving linear systems. Unfortunately I have one bottleneck which is extracting submatrices

from the big sparse matrix. This should be an O(n log n) operation but it seems that the current implementation is infuriatingly slow and O(n^2). I have found some closed threads on discourse but it is unclear what the current status is on that. Any hints?

messages.text: Is there anything harmful or discouraged about using `Base.remove_linenums!` inside a macro?

elements.text: Is there anything harmful or discouraged about using

messages.text: The downside is that it might make errors harder to pinpoint

elements.text: The downside is that it might make errors harder to pinpoint

messages.text:
For example,
```julia> macro identity(ex)
           esc(Base.remove_linenums!(ex))
       end
@identity (macro with 1 method)

julia> @identity begin
           x = 1 + 1
           y = 2x + "hi"
       end
ERROR: MethodError: no method matching +(::Int64, ::String)
Stacktrace:
 [1] top-level scope
   @ REPL[10]:1```

elements.text:
julia> macro identity(ex)
           esc(Base.remove_linenums!(ex))
       end
@identity (macro with 1 method)

julia> @identity begin
           x = 1 + 1
           y = 2x + "hi"
       end
ERROR: MethodError: no method matching +(::Int64, ::String)
Stacktrace:
 [1] top-level scope
   @ REPL[10]:1

messages.text:
Versus
```julia> begin
           x = 1 + 1
           y = 2x + "hi"
       end
ERROR: MethodError: no method matching +(::Int64, ::String)
Stacktrace:
 [1] top-level scope
   @ REPL[11]:3```
This one tells you it was line 3 in the input that produced the error

elements.text:
julia> begin
           x = 1 + 1
           y = 2x + "hi"
       end
ERROR: MethodError: no method matching +(::Int64, ::String)
Stacktrace:
 [1] top-level scope
   @ REPL[11]:3
This one tells you it was line 3 in the input that produced the error
